content.text: *Rugby rallies after ex-England captain Lewis Moody's MND diagnosis*

Former England rugby captain and 2003 World Cup winner Lewis Moody, 47, announced he has been diagnosed with motor neurone disease (ALS) and said he intends to stay positive. He reported minor symptoms, including “a bit of muscle wasting in the hand and the shoulder”. Teammates and supporters quickly mobilised, with a GoFundMe set up by Leicester greats Geordan Murphy and Leon Lloyd and a pledge of support from Kevin Sinfield.
*Rangers sack Martin after one league win; recruitment begins*

Rangers dismissed head coach Russell Martin after a four-month tenure that yielded only one league win. The club acknowledged the hiring "did not get this right" and said a rigorous recruitment process to appoint a successor is under way. Bookmakers have installed former boss Steven Gerrard as the early favourite for a return while reports suggest multiple candidates are being assessed.
*Debate grows over Postecoglou's future after winless start*

Scrutiny on Nottingham Forest manager Ange Postecoglou intensified after a 2-0 defeat to Newcastle United on Sunday left his side still winless under his tenure. Reports diverged on Forest’s next move: one outlet says he has a stay of execution, while another claims a sacking is now more likely than not. On BBC’s Monday Night Club, Chris Sutton described calls for his dismissal as "ridiculous" and labelled some fans "entitled".
*Lakers star LeBron James teases 'second decision' announcement*

LeBron James posted a nine-second video on X teasing "the second decision," saying an announcement will come Tuesday at 12 p.m. EST. The teaser sparked retirement speculation and coincided with a surge in secondary-market prices for the Lakers' home finale against the Jazz, according to Vivid Seats data cited by ESPN.
*McLaren secure constructors' title, debate Norris-Piastri fight*

McLaren have clinched a second straight constructors' championship with six events remaining, sitting on 650 points—exactly double Mercedes' tally. Team principal Andrea Stella said the team face difficulties managing Lando Norris and Oscar Piastri in the title run-in, while pundits question whether to allow a 'gloves-off' intra-team battle. The Singapore Grand Prix, won by George Russell, saw Piastri, Norris and Max Verstappen finish behind him, influencing the 2025 drivers' title picture.
*England captain Harry Kane open to new Bayern deal*

Harry Kane said his interest in a Premier League return has cooled and that he is willing to open talks with Bayern Munich over a new contract. The Independent also notes Tottenham’s new manager Thomas Frank has offered a way back, but the likelihood of a return is diminishing as Kane describes himself as “all in” with Bayern.
*Cardinals coach Gannon apologizes for sideline outburst at Demercado*

Arizona Cardinals head coach Jonathan Gannon said he apologized to running back Emari Demercado on Monday after a heated sideline exchange that followed the player's unforced fumble in Sunday's 22-21 loss to the Tennessee Titans. He added that the interaction was not reflective of who he is or wants to be.
*British No 1 Raducanu retires ill at Wuhan Open*

British number one Emma Raducanu retired from her Wuhan Open first-round match against Ann Li in the second set while trailing 6-1, 4-1. She took a medical timeout to have her blood pressure checked and cited dizziness amid hot, humid conditions around 31C in Wuhan.
*Former NFL quarterback Mark Sanchez faces felony battery charge*

Officials in Indianapolis announced on Monday that former NFL quarterback and Fox Sports analyst Mark Sanchez faces a Level 5 felony battery charge, which carries a potential one- to six-year sentence. The charge stems from an altercation early Saturday with a 69-year-old truck driver that left Sanchez hospitalized with stab wounds and the driver with "very severe" injuries; prosecutors said additional charges are possible. The alleged victim has also filed a civil lawsuit, according to the Los Angeles Times.
*UEFA allows league matches abroad in US and Australia*

UEFA said it "reluctantly" approved one La Liga match in the United States and one Serie A match in Australia this season, calling the move exceptional and not a precedent. Barcelona are set to face Villarreal in Miami in December, while Milan have been permitted to play Como in Perth in February, both still requiring FIFA sign-off.
*Dodgers hold off Phillies, seize 2-0 NLDS lead*

The Los Angeles Dodgers edged the Philadelphia Phillies 4-3 in Game 2 of the NL Division Series on Monday in Philadelphia to take a 2-0 lead in the best-of-five. Blake Snell struck out nine over six shutout innings before a late defensive clinic — including a textbook wheel play and a Freddie Freeman scoop — helped the Dodgers escape a ninth-inning jam. Game 3 is Wednesday in Los Angeles, where the Dodgers can clinch a return to the NLCS with a win.
*Jacksonville Jaguars edge Chiefs 31-28 on Lawrence's late TD*

Trevor Lawrence scored on a one-yard run with 23 seconds left to lift the Jacksonville Jaguars over the Kansas City Chiefs, 31-28, on Monday night in Jacksonville. The winning play came after Lawrence stumbled on the snap, recovered and broke a tackle before diving into the end zone. The victory moved Jacksonville to 4-1 and ended an eight-game skid against Kansas City dating to 2009; the Chiefs fell to 2-3.
